posts.name:
Nuwpur Jain
Nuwpur Jain
posts.content:
My dadi died 7 days back BUT she lived an absolutely full life which shocks me even today

Here's what made her extraordinary:

1) The Family Matriarch: She nurtured an incredible legacy of 51 hearts - 6 children, 18 grandchildren, and 27 great-grandchildren. Each one carrying a piece of her boundless love.

2) The Eternal Explorer: At 80+, she had the curiosity of a 21-year-old, traveling from Singapore to Dubai, and finally to Ram Mandir - living life with more enthusiasm than people a quarter her age.

3) The Graceful Goodbye: Seven days ago, she left us exactly how she lived - peacefully, having fulfilled all her wishes, and without suffering. A perfect ending to a life lived perfectly.

Here's to you, Dadi - forever young, forever loved ï¸

comments.commentText: Nuwpur, your tribute to your grandmother beautifully captures the essence of a remarkable life well-lived. Her legacy of love and curiosity is truly inspiring and serves as a reminder of how to embrace life fully, regardless of age. Thank you for sharing such heartfelt memories.
Priyank Ahuja Living proof that the best things in life come without an expiry date

posts.name:
Kendall Ware, CFE
Kendall Ware, CFE
posts.content:
12 Moments of Gratitude: Reflecting on an Incredible Year (3 of 12)

 Moment 3/12: The Power of Relationships

Iâ€™m beyond grateful for the incredible relationships Iâ€™ve built over the years in the restaurant and franchising industry.

These connections have not only shaped my journey but also led to some of the most meaningful momentsâ€”like one unforgettable dinner at the Restaurant Finance & Development Conference in Las Vegas last November. ()

It started with two separate conversations. Based on the projects Iâ€™m working on, my good friendtold me I needed to meet someone named. Just 15 minutes later, I ran into another good friendand as we were catching up, he said the exact same thing: â€œYou need to meet Louis.â€ And then, almost like it was meant to be, I got a text from Louis himself.

Louis, his partner Steve, and I met up briefly before dinner to run through introductions and share our backgrounds. In just a short time, we created a fast connectionâ€”one of those rare bonds where everything clicks, and you feel like youâ€™ve known each other much longer.

That evening, I joined,,,, and Jim Ellis for dinner.

For the first time in a long time, I found myself surrounded by like-minded people Iâ€™d never met before but who felt instantly familiar. We shared stories, wisdom, and so many mutual connections that the night was filled with laughter, mentorship, and new perspectives.

What made it even more special was hearing Louis share his journey of founding, growing, and successfully exiting his company,.

His story, along with the generous advice and encouragement from everyone at the table, left me inspired, motivated, and deeply appreciative.

I had an important event that evening, one I would normally prioritize, but something told me to take this opportunity instead. Iâ€™m so glad I followed my instincts.

This dinner wasnâ€™t just a meetingâ€”it was a powerful reminder of the importance of relationships.

Whether itâ€™s reconnecting with familiar faces or meeting someone entirely new, the connections we make can lead to opportunities, inspiration, and growth in ways we canâ€™t always anticipate.

Itâ€™s easy to stick with whatâ€™s familiar at conferences, but sometimes the greatest value comes from following your instincts and leaning into new relationships.

You never know when a simple introduction might spark new ideas, inspire fresh perspectives, or open the door to something greater.

Hereâ€™s to the people who inspire us, the relationships that shape us, and the opportunities to grow through shared wisdom and purpose.

posts.content:
"Claire, I almost...
had to unfollow you" 

...he joked. 

(a client of mine in December)

"But seriously, every time I'm on LinkedIn
You're there in my feed.
You're everywhere!"

Coincidence?

No way.
I want you to see me.
Here. There. Everywhere on social.

It's a selfish reason, really.


Bc the more of you are in the roles you enjoy
The significantly better healthcare the rest of us can receive
As more providers and hospitals have more resources and support

So what?


Well...an MD saved my life in 2016 with lifesaving tech he needed to fix a 2-day DVT.

And

he could not have done it w/o the rep who introduced, supplied, and supported him with the technology.


So, am I grinding it out every day on LinkedIn
(and soon YouTube,)?

All day.

I'm not here (just) for the fun of it.
I'm here to reach a specific stretch goal:

My goal is to help 150+ Medical Sales Professionals land the 6-figure roles they rave about by 12/31/2025

...with resumes and linkedin profiles that sell YOU like YOU sell a product in the last month of Q4 of a product launch.

It's go time.

Will you be next?

DM me.

posts.name:
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong

Josue Valles
Josue Valles
posts.content:
7 ways to show youâ€™re an expert 

(without saying youâ€™re an expert):

The best "expert" I met fixes cars in a tiny garage in Tijuana, Mexico.

He never calls himself an expert. But I noticed something about how he works with customers:

When someone brings their Mercedes with a weird sound, he listens. Then he tells them about three other cars that made the same noise last month.

He explains what caused it, what didn't work, and what fixed it.

You see, true experts don't tell. They show.

Here are 7 signs someone knows their stuff (beyond certificates or followers):

1. They can answer questions at multiple depths

A kid asks how planes fly? They talk about birds. A pilot asks? They break down wing design and air pressure. They match their answer to who asks.

2. They adapt their vocabulary

A chef talks about "reduction" with other chefs. But with home cooks? "We're just boiling this sauce until it gets thicker." Same concept, different words.

3. They stay calm explaining basics

Picture a math teacher. The good ones never mock students for counting on fingers. They remember when they did it too.

4. They admit their failures

"Want to see my first painting? It's terrible." Art teachers who show their early work help students more than those who only display masterpieces.

5. They point to others' work

Ask a basketball coach about shooting form? They'll say "Watch how Steph Curry does it." Great teachers share their heroes.

6. They spot patterns

A doctor hears your symptoms and remembers similar cases. Not because they're smart - because they've seen it before. Experience beats memorization.

7. They say "I don't know"

The best teachers admit when they're stumped. They turn "I don't know" into "Let's find out together."

Practical takeaway for creatives:

Don't call yourself an expert. Let your work prove you are one.

â€”

For a limited time, get my curation workshop for only $19.

Link in bio.

comments.commentText: Admitting failure is key. How can you improve if you donâ€™t even believe thereâ€™s room for improvement in the first place?

posts.name:
Alexandra Flax
Alexandra Flax
posts.content:
Whatâ€™s your best advice to someone trying to get into medical sales? 

ï¸ Do whatever it takes.

Every person you talk to will probably give you a different piece of advice. Mine is simple. Do whatever you have to do to get the job. This is all encompassing. It includes the networking. It includes the follow ups. It includes consistency. It includes commitment. It IS action.

It is the do whatever it takes mentality. Itâ€™s worth it.

comments.commentText:
Absolutely spot on!  

The "do whatever it takes" mentality is what sets successful candidates apart, especially in a competitive field like medical sales.
Networking and follow-ups are game-changers, but Iâ€™d also add one thing: be relentless in learning the industry.

Knowing the products, the challenges healthcare professionals face, and how your solutions can make an impact will set you up for success once you land the role.

The journey into medical sales might not be easy, but the combination of consistency, action, and the willingness to go above and beyond is what makes it all worth it.
